repnme.cdata!: Strengthening the justice sector in Honduras

abstracts.cdata!:
A World Bank project in Honduras has
            helped make justice accessible to many people who previously
            struggled with an inefficient, outdated, opaque judicial
            system. Through a range of activities, from training
            judicial and administrative staff to modernizing financial
            systems and refurbishing facilities, the project has helped
            to open the judicial branch to more than 1.9 million
            Hondurans in the project areas.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Judicial Branch Modernization
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Judicial Branch Modernization
            Project will support implementation of the judicial branch
            modernization plan 2004-2009.  The project aims to improve
            the capacity and performance of the judicial branch in three
            areas: 1) greater efficiency of case processing, judgments
            and appeals, 2) enhanced transparency and accountability,
            and 3) better access to justice, especially for the most
            disadvantaged groups. The changes are of second order
            category: cancellation of SDR 0.64 million, or US$1 million
            equivalent, and extension of the closing date from March 31,
            2011 until June 30, 2011. The restructuring paper will not
            change the Project Development Objective (PDO). The
            extension will ensure that the PDO is fully achieved, as a
            set of key activities will be fully completed. The extension
            of the closing date will ensure the completion of the
            pending activities and the raising of the disbursement ratio
            by the revised closing date up to 100 percent. This is the
            second extension of the closing date, up to nine months from
            the project's original closing date.

6449031.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Honduras Judicial Branch
            Modernization Project supports implementation of the
            Judicial Branch Modernization Plan 2004-2009.   The project
            will be achieved through the following four inter-related
            components: A. Improvement of the Efficiency of Judicial
            Services to strengthen operational capabilities of the
            Judicial Branch to more efficiently process cases, issue
            judgments, and review appeals. B. Enhancing Judicial
            Accountability and Transparency to enhance Judicial Branch
            accountability and transparency standards. C. Promoting
            Equitable Access to Justice to address shortages and
            disparities in justice services, especially for the
            disadvantaged. D. Project Coordination, Monitoring and
            Evaluation to strengthen institutional capability,
            mobilization for change, oversight of the modernization
            program process, and donor coordination.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Judicial Branch Modernization
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall development objective of the
            Honduras - Judicial Branch Modernization Project is to
            improve Judicial Branch performance, especially with respect
            to efficiency, transparency, and access. The IPP report
            evaluated impacts to indigenous population which includes :
            health, education and access to basic services; lack of
            secure land tenure; infectious diseases (AIDS is a serious
            problem among the Garifuna population); geographical
            isolation; social and economic exclusion; and language
            barriers. Some of the mitigation measures included in the
            IPP are : inform indigenous communities about their legal
            rights; support the reactivation of the office for Special
            Prosecution for Ethics and Cultural Heritage; improve access
            to judicial services for Honduras' ethnic minorities
            and enforce the need to incorporate gender sensitivity and
            social empowerment initiatives into the judicial system;
            develop training plans for judges and judicial operators in
            areas with ethnic populations; a social empowerment
            specialist will be hired with expertise in indigenous
            peoples and Garifuna issues; promote greater use of
            alternative dispute resolution (ADR) mechanisms, and
            finally, promote citizen outreach programs on legal rights
            and responsibilities in partnership with NGOs and civil
            society organizations.
